> Please rebase on main, I expect there will be some conflicts. But the tests you mention should probably work out fine.

Done, the issues have been resolved.

> Would you mind adding another test and adding a jira link? This may help new developers understand it later.

The case I mentioned in JIRA has been fixed from the root cause in [Commit](https://github.com/apache/calcite/commit/c7cace6cca8916875c6b5dc5b51089d608d97e47).
So this PR mainly optimizes union with values plan, there are already enough test in SqlToRelConverterTest, so I didn't add new test cases.

> no need to file an issue for such small changes

@mihaibudiu I don't fully agree with this suggestion. It maybe be OK to skip JIRA for typos, whitespaces etc., but for actual code changes I find it useful to have JIRA ids for the reasons I expressed in https://lists.apache.org/thread/3xx1rdzgnh44ykdm8xlvgn630b60m8vb
Removed the "merge" label until the discussion in JIRA is settled.

> > no need to file an issue for such small changes
> 
> @mihaibudiu I don't fully agree with this suggestion. It maybe be OK to skip JIRA for typos, whitespaces etc., but for actual code changes I find it useful to have JIRA ids for the reasons I expressed in https://lists.apache.org/thread/3xx1rdzgnh44ykdm8xlvgn630b60m8vb

@zabetak I think this part can be updated to the Calcite documentation to facilitate the review of subsequent PRs

body: This design is based on a discussion on the mailing list. Many thanks to all the people who helped drive this design.
hi @chunweilei , when time to merge this pull request. I think UDTF is useful feature for SQL . Thanks a lot

> This design is based on a discussion on the mailing list. Many thanks to all the people who helped drive this design.

Looks really cool. Could you please post the link to the discussion on the mailing list so people can know the whole story?

The codebase has changed significantly in the last 4 years since this PR was submitted, so some work will be needed to rebase this. I agree it would be a useful feature to have.

Note that Calcite does support table functions, but they are invoked with the TABLE syntax: https://calcite.apache.org/docs/reference.html#table-functions
This is the email thread: https://lists.apache.org/list?dev@calcite.apache.org:2024-10:checked
If no one else has comments I plan to merge this as 4 commits, which close 3 issues.

> Frankly, I think it's useful to have non-English locale examples and tests. Perhaps you can keep the Chinese one and add the English one?

This is a good idea, I'll add English instructions and describe how to get different results with the locale parameter.

body: I marked this as ready to merge, but I will wait a couple of days for more comments, since it's an important change.

Before this PR, When the subquery is SqlNodeList, this subquery will be a special case for `config.isExpand`, After this PR, we convert the SqlNodeList to a RexSubquery, then can handled by SubqueryRemoveRule.

> Has the behavior of isExpand changed with this PR (other than producing a correct result for queries that were wrong)

`isExpand` only changed the behavior when the subquery is a SqlNodeList. Others stay the same.

This does not explain what kinds of SQL program this affects.
SqlNodeList is a very general data structure.
Can this only happen when there is a list of expressions?
Can the expressions refer to correlated variables, for example?
I think this is a reasonable approach and there is no need to maintain the logic when expand is false. But it is incompatible with previous versions.

At the very least I believe breaking changes have to be documented in history.md.
But first I would like to understand what is actually affected. Could you make a short summary of programs that will compile differently after this change? Seems like the JIRA issue is the right place.
If the only change is to compile correctly programs that were previously causing a compiler bug or an incorrect output, then this is not a breaking change.

The codebase has already "minimization" code in various other places (e.g., `RelMdUniqueKeys#filterSupersets`) and there is overlapping functionality with the new `ImmutableBitSet#isMinimal` API.
Based on these findings, I don't think a new API is necessary thus I [reverted](https://github.com/apache/calcite/pull/4013/commits/1e3b09a02bf465320b327de9714ec30c12e29e65) the respective code changes from.

If we want to add a new public API its better to refactor/use the existing "minimization" logic.
However, the refactoring will require some discussion on where to move the code and how we want the API to look like so it is out of the scope of this PR.

If there are no objections I plan to merge this PR as is in ~24hrs. If people feel that we need more work on the minimization checks/logic let me know and we can discuss this under a dedicated JIRA.

body: @ninidhiaeddine We need a unit test for this change.

> @ninidhiaeddine We need a unit test for this change.

I was thinking to add a unit test for this change, but I didn't find any existing unit tests that are checking the returned `Strong.Policy` for a given `SqlOperator`.

The only unit tests that I found to be remotely related are: `SqlOperatorTest#testPowerFun()` and `SqlOperatorTest#testPowerDecimalFunc()` which check that `POWER(2, NULL)` and `POWER(NULL, 2)` both return `NULL`. However, none of these methods make any call to `Strong.policy(arg)`.

Any ideas on what to test here exactly? Please let me know.

> > @ninidhiaeddine We need a unit test for this change.
> 
> I was thinking to add a unit test for this change, but I didn't find any existing unit tests that are checking the returned `Strong.Policy` for a given `SqlOperator`.
> 
> The only unit tests that I found to be remotely related are: `SqlOperatorTest#testPowerFun()` and `SqlOperatorTest#testPowerDecimalFunc()` which check that `POWER(2, NULL)` and `POWER(NULL, 2)` both return `NULL`. However, none of these methods make any call to `Strong.policy(arg)`.
> 
> Any ideas on what to test here exactly? Please let me know.

@ninidhiaeddine Hi. You can add tests in sqloperatortest

> @ninidhiaeddine Hi. You can add tests in sqloperatortest

Could you please clarify?
The only relevant check I can do is `Assert.assertEquals(Strong.Policy.ANY, Strong.policy(SqlStdOperatorTable.POWER)` but it would be out of context as none of the existing test methods in this class currently validate the `Strong.Policy` of the `SqlOperator`s. What do you think?

The Strong class is used during optimizations.
The JavaDoc for Strong says "Utilities for strong predicates."
However, POWER is not a predicate.
So I don't know whether this change has any effect.
It is not easy to audit all the places where Strong is used in the codebase to determine whether it will have any effect on any program. Most places I could find only simplify predicates.
I don't know if this has any effect on the *_REDUCE_EXPRESSIONS set of optimization rules, where perhaps POWER with a constant null argument could be simplified to NULL at compile-time.
Do you have an example which is affected by this issue?
BTW: there is another class NullPolicy which seems to overlap in functionality with Strong. That class is used during code-generation for the Enum interpreter.

The only place where the Policy is actually used is in RexSimplify, where it is used to check whether some expressions are always null. So perhaps you can can write a SqlToRelConverter test that checks to see whether the call to POWER(null, x) is replaced in the program with a constant NULL.
Since Strong provides only a conservative approximation, AS_IS is not wrong, it may be just a missed optimization opportunity.

I have added the change in Conformance as a breaking change to the history.md file.
I have squashed the commits in preparation for merging, but will wait a bit more for comments.

body: @mihaibudiu have you seen the Windows failures like the ones on this PR before? They look unrelated but thought I'd ask?

I have seen similar errors in windows builds, but not this many... they usually go away if you rerun the failed jobs.
Must be some problem with the build machines.

You need some unit tests.
You should reconcile the JIRA title with this one.
Could you suggest another good test class to add to? There are some in `core/src/test/java/org/apache/calcite/rex/RexNormalizeTest.java`
It would be great to have a test that reproduces the NPE that is mentioned in the JIRA issue.
